awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Categorization and Segmentation Inside and Outside Language
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans hear the speech of others almost every day.  Understanding that speech is often quite difficult, as can be seen when interacting with automated speech recognition technologies.  Doing so requires the use of complex yet surprisingly effective cognitive abilities.  But are the mental tools that humans use to understand speech used for speech only, or are there ones that are applied to multiple purposes?  This project seeks to link language learning and perception to other tasks to determine the extent to which speech perception shares an underlying basis with other cognitive processes.  This project will enrich the understanding of cognition.  Furthermore, it could open up new avenues for designing technologies to better improve speech processing as well as lead to new methodologies to train people learning a second language.

To study the domain-specificity of speech perception, this project will center on two particular aspects of speech: category learning and segmentation.  Accurate comprehension of spoken language demands the segmentation of continuous speech into discrete words, just as the perception of actions demands the segmentation of perceived activity into discrete events.  And listeners must learn to deal with the variability in speech sounds in order to treat some sounds as belonging to the same category, just as they must group, say, disparate dog sounds as belonging to a single "barking" category.  One experiment will investigate the extent to which rate information can affect the segmentation of events, while another will assess the extent to which biases that seem to be present in phonetic category learning can also be found in non-speech category learning.  A third experiment will use magnetoencephalography (MEG) to probe the acquisition of certain types of speech sound categories.  All told, the research will illuminate whether and which processes in language and in other domains parallel each other, which relates to the notion of modularity, the idea that the brain houses separate components that have evolved to perform individual functions in the world.

por.por_cntn:
This project centered on domain-specificity in language perception - the extent to which the processes used to understand language are the same as those outside language, or to the extent to which they are different. To study this, the researchers involved on the project examined domain-specificity in two different paradigms.  In a test of learning, the learning of speech sound categories was compared to the learning of categories of musical instrument sounds. In a test of adaptation, adapting to variation in speech rate was compared to adapting to variation in the rate of different visual events.  Our goal was to see to what extent patterns of performance in the tasks outside of language resembled those found inside language.

In the end, the results of the two experiments diverged from each other. In the learning tasks, the biases that participants show against certain types of categories in the language domain were not replicated in for the musical instrument categories. This suggests a level of domain-specificity in the biases that listeners bring to the table when learning speech sound categories. In the adaptation tasks, meanwhile, the rate adaptation seen in language was successfully replicated in the perception of visual events. This indicates that there may be some common mechanisms that can explain the perception of timing in the two domains.

These projects were used as the primary studies in the doctoral dissertation of the co-PI, and will lead to several published papers, including some currently in the publication pipeline. This is one of the first studies of rate adaptation in the perception of events, and one of the few tasks to specifically examine the learning of auditory categories to assess domain-specificity, rather than simply perception or discrimination. This work also has implications for the broader community. Understanding more about domain-specificity can help in building better technology that can adapt to changing circumstances and better teaching materials that leverage the abilities learners can bring to bear on a language learning task. During the course of the project, the student co-PI also mentored multiple undergraduate students who were underrepresented minorities, and has also gone on to bolster a collaboration between his postdoctoral institution and a local science museum.
